div.sent: Election is the foundation of modern democracy.
In this system, the citizens elect their representative from more than one candidate.
This procedure of election is run through secret vote.
The candidates who in the election according to the results of vote form national and local level governments, participate in legislation and run the administration.
In our country, elections are held for Union Parishad, Pourashava, Upazila Parishad, City Corporation, National Assembly and even for the post of the President.
The process of Presidential Election varies from Union Parishad, Pourashava or even National Assembly elections.
The true democracy can be established in a country if only the fittest representatives are elected through free and fair election.
Nowadays, the area of the state has been expanded and her population also has become huge.
As a result, the people cannot directly participate in administration and in legislation.
For this, the people are to elect their representatives to conduct the state affairs in favour of them.
This process of electing representatives is run through voting.
Through voting, the people not only elect their representatives, but also express their opinions about what type of administrative system they want.
From this point of view, there is no alternative to election in a modern state.
In the present world, democracy is considered the best among all the prevailing administrative systems.
And election is the foundation of democracy.
The main purpose of democracy is to take decisions on the basis of the citizens opinions.
And election is the main and lawful process of expressing public opinion.
So, democracy cannot be possible without election.
Election system is mainly of two types: Direct Election and Indirect Election.
When the citizens elect their representatives directly through casting their votes, this election is called direct election.
In our country, the members of Jatiyo Sangsad are elected through direct election system.
In this process the citizens do not elect their representatives directly through casting votes.
Here the election is held by two steps.
At first, the citizens by casting their votes directly elect member for a representative councilor for an intermediary level.
Then the representatives elect the final representative through voting.
In Bangladesh, the Presidential election and the election of reserved seats for women are held through such indirect election process.
For example, our President is not elected directly by the vote of the citizens.
During the general election, the citizens elect members of Jatiyo Sangsad through voting.
These elected members elect the President through casting their votes.
Similarly, the members for reserved seats for women are not elected directly by the citizens.
The elected members of Jatiyo Sangsad can cast their votes for electing members for those seats.
The differences between the direct and indirect elections have been presented below through a diagram.
Generally three types of elections are held at the national level in Bangladesh.
Jatiyo Sangsad Election: There are 300 seats in our Jatiyo Sangsad.
These 300 members are elected directly by the voters of the whole country.
There are also 50 reserved seats for women.
They are elected by the votes of the 300 members of Jatiyo Sangsad, who are directly elected by the people.
Though each of them is elected form a particular area, these 350 members represent the whole country.
They legislate for the country and play role in policy making.
The government of our country is formed by the support of the majority members of Jatiyo Sangshad.
From this point of view, this is the most important national level election.
Election of the President: The election of the President is also a national level election.
This election is not held directly.
It is held indirectly.
Referendum: Referendum is held for the verification of public opinion on any important issue of the state.
This is not held in the gap of a definite period.
Referendum may be held any time if necessity arises.
The discussion about these local governments is as follows.
Union Parishad: Union Parishads are village based.
At present, there are 4498 Union Parishads in our country.
There are one Chairman, nine general members and three reserved seats for the female members in each Union Parishad.
Each of them is directly elected by the people for a period of five years.
Upazila Parishad Election: At present there are 483 Upazilas in the country.
There is a Upazila Parishad in each Upazila.
This Upazila Parishad is formed by an elected chairman, some general members and for reserved seats some female members.
Upazila chairman is directly elected by the votes of the people of concerned area for five years.
Pourashava Election: Pourashava is urban based government form.
At present in the country there are 309 Pourashavas.
There are one chairman, several Commissioners and some reserved seats for some female commissioners in a Pourashava.
They are directly elected by the voters of Pourashava for five years.
City Corporation: At present, there are six metropolitan cities in Bangladesh.
These are Dhaka, Chittagong, Rajshahi, Khulna, Barisal and Sylhet.
Besides these six metropolitan cities, in Comilla and Narayangonj, there are city corporations.
The chief of the City Corporation is the Mayor.
Every city corporation is divided into several general wards.
For each ward there is one Commissioner.
The Mayor and the Commissioners are elected by the direct vote of the people of the concerned area for five years.
Zila Parishad Election: There is one Zila Parishad in each of 61 districts except the three Hill Tract districts in Bangladesh.
Zila Parishad is formed by a chairman, 15 members and five female members for reserved seats.
They are not elected by the direct votes of the people.
Rather they are elected by the electorate of the concerned area.
The duration of zila parishad is five years.
Hill Tract Zila Parishad Election: There are three Hill Tract districts in Bangladesh.
These are Rangamati, Khagrachari and Bandarban.
There is a Hill Tract Zilla Parishad in each Hill Tract district.
There are a Chairman, a definite number of tribal and non-tribal members in each Hill Tract Zila Parishad.
They are directly elected by the voters of concerned Hill Tract district for five years.
By-election: There is a provision for by-election with regard to the above mentioned election.
By-election is held if any seat of an elected member falls vacant due to death, resignation or for any other reason.
